statement.p: What is the integral that results when the substitution u= \sin x is applied to the integral \displaystyle \int_0^{\pi/2} f(\sin x)\,\dee{x}?

answer.p: \displaystyle\int_{0}^{1} \frac{f(u)}{\sqrt{1-u^2}}\,\dee{u}. Because the denominator \sqrt{1-u^2} vanishes when u=1, this is what is known as an improper integral. Improper integrals will be discussed in Section.

solution.p:
We substitute:
u&=\sin x,
\dee{u}&=\cos x\,\dee{x},
\cos x &= \sqrt{1-\sin^2 x}=\sqrt{1-u^2},
\dee{x} &=\dfrac{\dee{u}}{\cos x} = \dfrac{\dee{u}}{\sqrt{1-u^2}}
u(0)&=\sin 0 = 0
u\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)&=\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)=1
So, \int_{x=0}^{x=\pi/2} f(\sin x)\,\dee{x} &= \int_{u=0}^{u=1} f(u)\,\frac{\dee{u}}{\sqrt{1-u^2}}
Because the denominator \sqrt{1-u^2} vanishes when u=1, this is what is known as an improper integral. Improper integrals will be discussed in Section.

statement.p: Let f and g be functions that are continuous and differentiable everywhere. Simplify \int f'(g(x))g'(x)\dee{x} - f(g(x)).

hint.p: What is \diff{}{x}\{f(g(x))\}?

solution.p:
Using the chain rule, we see that
\diff{}{x}\{f(g(x))\}=f'(g(x))g'(x)

So, \textcolor{red}{f(g(x))} is an antiderivative of \textcolor{red}{f'(g(x))g'(x)}. All antiderivatives of f'(g(x))g'(x) differ by only a constant, so:
\textcolor{red}{\int f'(g(x))g'(x)\dee{x}} - f(g(x))&=\textcolor{red}{f(g(x))+C}-f(g(x))
&=C
That is, our expression simplifies to some constant C.

Remark: since
\int f'(g(x))g'(x)\dee{t} - f(g(x))=C

we conclude
\int f'(g(x))g'(x)\dee{t} = f(g(x))+C
which is precisely how we perform substitution on integrals.

ul.li:
Solution 1: If we let \textcolor{red}{u=\sqrt{\log x}}, then \textcolor{blue}{\dee{u}=\dfrac{1}{2x\sqrt{\log x}}\dee{x}}, and:
\int \dfrac{e^{\textcolor{red}{\sqrt{\log x}}}}{\textcolor{blue}{2x\sqrt{\log x}}}\ \textcolor{blue}{\dee{x}}&=\int e^{\textcolor{red}u}\ \textcolor{blue}{\dee{u}}=e^u+C=e^{\sqrt{\log x}}+C

hint.p: There is a short, slightly sneaky method guess an antiderivative and a really short, still-more-sneaky method.

ul.li:
The slightly sneaky method: We note that \displaystyle\diff{}{x} \left\{e^{x^2} \right\}= 2x\, e^{x^2}, so that \dfrac{1}{2} e^{x^2} is a antiderivative for the integrand x e^{x^2}. So
\int_{-2}^2 xe^{x^2}\,\dee{x} = \bigg[\frac{1}{2}e^{x^2}\bigg]_{-2}^2 =\frac{1}{2}e^4-\frac{1}{2}e^4=0
The really sneaky method: The integrand f(x) = x e^{x^2} is an odd function (meaning that f(-x)=-f(x)). So by Theorem every integral of the form \int_{-a}^a x e^{x^2}\,\dee{x} is zero.

introduction.p: Questions through can be solved by substitution, but it may not be obvious which substitution will work. In general, when evaluating integrals, it is not always immediately clear which methods are appropriate. If this happens to you, don't despair, and definitely don't give up! Just guess a method and try it. Even if it fails, you'll probably learn something that you can use to make a better guess. This is also pretty decent life advice.

solution.p:
The given sum is of the form
\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{j=1}^n \frac{j}{n^2}\cos\Big(\frac{j^2}{n^2}\Big) =\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{j=1}^n f(x_j^*)\De x
with \De x=\frac{1}{n}, x_j^*=\frac{j}{n} and f(x)=x\cos(x^2). Since x_0^*=0 and x_n^*=1, the right hand side is the definition (using the right Riemann sum) of
\int_0^1 f(x)\,\dee{x} &=\int_0^1 \textcolor{blue}{x}\cos(\textcolor{red}{x^2})\,\textcolor{blue}{\dee{x}}
&=\textcolor{blue}{\frac{1}{2}}\int_0^1 \cos(\textcolor{red}{y})\,\textcolor{blue}{\dee{y} }\qquad\text{with } \textcolor{red}{y=x^2}, \textcolor{blue}{\dee{y}=2x\,\dee{x}}
&=\frac{1}{2}\Big[\sin(y)\Big]_0^1
&=\frac{1}{2}\sin 1

statement.p:
Using Riemann sums, prove that
\int_a^b 2f(2x)\dee{x} = \int_{2a}^{2b} f(x)\dee{x}

hint.p: Find the right Riemann sum for both definite integrals.

solution.p: Looking at the Riemann sum in this way is instructive, because it is very clear why the two integrals should be equal (without using substitution). The rectangles in the first Riemann sum are half as wide, but twice as tall, as the rectangles in the second Riemann sum. So, the two Riemann sums have rectangles of the same area.

In the integral on the left, the variable is red \textcolor{red}{x} and in the integral on the right, the variable is blue \textcolor{blue}{x}. Red \textcolor{red}{x} and blue \textcolor{blue}{x} are not the same. In fact 2\textcolor{red}{x_i^*}=\textcolor{blue}{x_i^*}. (Not every substitution corresponds to such a simple picture.)
